awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: Investigation of the Relationship between Processing Conditions and Morphology of Lithium During Electroplating
awd_abstract_narration:
Graphite is currently used as the anode component in most rechargeable lithium-ion batteries. Replacing graphite with lithium metal holds the promise to improve the battery capacity by several times while also reducing costs. During battery charging and discharging, the lithium metal surface is prone to losing its smooth morphology and forms many sharp protrusions, a phenomenon, known as dendrite growth. Dendrite growth results in inferior battery life and induces severe safety concerns, both of which are major barriers to the commercialization of lithium-metal-based rechargeable batteries. This project aims to provide fundamental knowledge to guide the advanced manufacturing of lithium metal anodes with long cycle life and stability. It will focus on understanding the role of residual stress that accumulates within lithium metal during battery cycling in triggering lithium dendrite growth, and how its adverse effect can be eliminated by the design of a novel porous anode architecture. Integrated characterization, modeling and manufacturing activities will be carried out to achieve this goal. In addition to having major impacts on the development of next-generation batteries for electrical vehicles and electric grids, the mechanistic understanding acquired in the project will also facilitate the use of other earth-abundant metallic materials in energy storage devices. The integrated education and outreach component of the project will benefit a broad range of groups by providing authentic research experiences to native Americans and community college students, promoting undergraduate research and graduate education through active student recruitment and retention, and integrating the latest progress in battery research into curriculum on mechanics and materials science.

Despite extensive efforts, a complete understanding of the lithium dendrite growth mechanism has not yet been established. This project builds on the PIs' recent findings and will investigate stress as a key processing condition for controlling lithium surface morphology during electroplating, which has previously received little attention. It will combine in-situ and ex-situ characterizations, modeling and fabrication studies to: 1) understand how the stress, current density and plating time collectively control the lithium morphology; 2) construct a lithium  morphology diagram to predict lithium plating morphology as a function of controllable processing conditions, 3) apply the acquired knowledge to design lithium anode architecture that enables stable cycling under high current densities, and 4) explore a potential cost-competitive method to manufacture high-performance lithium anodes. This research is expected to provide essential scientific guidance for the manufacturing of stable lithium metal anode structures for high capacity rechargeable batteries.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_div_long_name: Division of Civil, Mechanical, and Manufacturing Innovation

por.por_cntn:
Overview: This project aims to understand the role of residual stress that accumulates within lithium metal in triggering lithium dendrite growth during battery cycling, and how its adverse effect can be eliminated through novel electrode designs. The project also aims to develop new, optical-based characterization methods for assessing the stress generation in situ during lithium plating. Integrated characterization, modeling and manufacturing activities were carried out to achieve this goal. 

 

Intellectual Merit: The project hypothesis is that residual stress arising from lithium metal electroplating onto hard, planar current collectors leads to dendritic growth, and that stress-relaxation using three-dimensional, soft substrates can allow for stable lithium plating. In the project, polymeric substrates such as polydimethylsiloxane (PDMS) and polyethylene terephthalate (PET) were coated with thin films of copper and used as current collector substrates for lithium plating. Investigation of mechanical stress during lithium plating and stripping processes on the Cu-coated PET substrates was monitored in situ using optically transparent, three-electrode electrochemical cells with the PET working electrodes suspended in a reservoir of electrolyte. During lithium plating, the deposition of lithium and accompanying stresses cause the working electrode to bend its initial position. The PI’s group developed a camera setup for monitoring the bending angle during the electrochemical cycling, which was converted to the lithium deposition stress using the Stoney formula. The measurements were performed with different current densities and also with pre-formation of the solid electrolyte interphase layer to understand the contribution of the electrolyte reduction and kinetics of the reaction on the stress generation. Additionally, a second in situ monitoring technique using the reflection of a helium-neon laser off of the reflective surface of the Cu-coated PET was preliminarily investigated. In this method, the displacement of the reflected beam can also be quantified to monitor the change in bending angle. 

 

In parallel, lithium plating and stripping processes were also carried out using representative hard solid electrolytes. The aim is to understand how the ion conducting medium (liquid vs solid) and use of soft current collector can affect the lithium plating processes and accompanying residual stresses using prepared pellets of the ceramic solid electrolyte, tantalum-doped lithium lanthanum zirconate (LLZTO). These pellets are translucent/white in color and lithium dendrites that growth through the pellets during lithium plating appear blackish. Therefore, the LLZTO materials could also serve as a platform for in situ optical monitoring during lithium deposition. To establish the baseline of performance, conventional lithium metal electrodes were contacted to the LLZTO pellet faces with metal current collectors and the critical current density (CCD) that leads to shorting was established. It was found that the CCD was highly dependent on the grain size of the LLZTO, with fine grained LLZTO allowing for higher CCD to be reached. This result contradicts other research from other groups showing that Li dendrites prefer to grow along grain boundaries, which suggests that fine grained LLZTO with high grain boundary area should be avoided. If the grain boundaries are nucleation sites for lithium dendrite growth, it is hypothesized that the observation may be explained by the distribution of the lithium plating stresses over a larger area of grain boundaries, which may actually lower the local stresses. To better understand this, a systematic study investigating the effect of grain boundaries on the properties of the LLZO was carried out. 

 

Broader Impacts: In addition to research mission, this project is expected to have major impacts on the development of metallic anodes for next-generation, ultrahigh capacity battery systems such as Li-sulfur and Li-air batteries. This study provided new systematic and mechanistic understanding of processing-Li morphology relationships with controllable factors, including stress level, plating current density and time. The combination of these factors, particularly the stress, has not been widely appreciated so far. Such an understanding is expected to open up an unexplored front in the intensive pursuit of effective ways to mitigating Li dendritic growth. Additionally, extending the stress relaxation and in situ optical characterization to solid electrolytes can lead to new insights that can help the further development of solid-state batteries using lithium metal anodes. In addition, this project has helped training of next generation of workforce in the advanced materials area, and knowledge gained from this project has been incorporated into graduate courses at ASU, thus impacting students' understanding of advancements in battery technologies. 

 


Last Modified: 04/27/2024
Modified by: Hongbin Yu
